message_1: What is the half-life of a radioactive element if 400 g of it decays to 50 g in 30 years?
message_2:
To find the half-life of a radioactive element, we can use the formula:

N(t) = N0 * (1/2)^(t/T)

where N(t) is the amount of the element remaining after time t, N0 is the initial amount of the element, t is the time elapsed, and T is the half-life of the element.

In this case, we have:

N(t) = 50 g
N0 = 400 g
t = 30 years

We want to find T, the half-life. Rearranging the formula to solve for T, we get:

T = t * (log(1/2) / log(N(t)/N0))

Plugging in the values:

T = 30 * (log(1/2) / log(50/400))
T = 30 * (log(1/2) / log(1/8))
T ≈ 30 * ( -0.3010 / -0.9031)
T ≈ 10 years

So, the half-life of the radioactive element is approximately 10 years.
